21.text: My name is Stuart Makin, and I’m a blacksmith.

27.text: Blacksmithing is the process of getting steel or iron hot, and hammering it with a hammer over an anvil until you get the shapes that you want.

34.text: It’s quite an old practice, dating back a few thousand years.

39.text: We use it today, combined with modern techniques as well, to reproduce

45.text:
things from history but also to create new
pieces of art and design.

50.text:
There’s a large range of items within the
Staffordshire Hoard, some of which haven’t

54.text:
even been identified and just identified as
‘item of gold’.

57.text:
A lot of items are sword fittings – sword
pommels and cross guards. There are some – more

65.text: unusually – seax hilts. Seax is an Anglo-Saxon knife, it’s the Old English word for knife.

70.text: The central motif for the sculpture is heavily inspired by one of the seax handles, the knife handles.

78.text:
It’s a round element of gold with
garnets fitted to it, and it would have made

85.text: the upper part of a knife handle. So you unfold this out, and it was a pair of dragons,

92.text:
one above the other.
Now I wanted my sculpture to draw from the

97.text: decorative elements of the Staffordshire Hoard, but also to try to convey how a piece would

105.text: have been made. So cloisonné, which is the process of setting stones into cells –

113.text: you form tiny little shapes, squares, circles and you set a stone or piece of enamel into it –

119.text:
I wanted to try and show that through the
progression of the sculpture.

122.text: So, at the bottom you have the outline chased into the steel, and as you move up you have

127.text:
these cells that are cut out – that open
section. And as you move through to the top,

132.text: it’s completed: you have the red, set against the gold, and it just shows a pathway from

139.text: beginning to completion of how they would have done this originally.

144.text: During my original creative process, I surrounded myself with pictures of items from the Staffordshire Hoard.

150.text:
By immersing yourself in it all the
time you begin to focus on the ones that you

156.text: like best, and you go through those ten favourite pictures and you decide: what is it? What

161.text: is it about this picture that I love so much? And once I discovered those elements, I then

169.text: tried to piece them together into something that would convey my feeling of the Staffordshire Hoard.

175.text: I pick the design from a knife handle, but

180.text: I pick the eagle from a sword mount, and then I do sketches, I do full-size drawings,

187.text: model making, and eventually you begin to piece together these jigsaw pieces until you

192.text:
stand back one day and you look at it and
go: “that’s great, that’s it, that’s

197.text:
what I need to make now. In full size, in
metal.”

202.text:
The sculpture is quite large-scale: it’s
two and a half metres tall by two metres wide.

208.text: It’s made of steel, and this has been coated with a high-pigment gold paint, to try and

215.text:
replicate that gold from the items in the
Staffordshire Hoard. And the red elements

221.text:
are a red perspex, so you get that really
interesting and striking colour contrast –

226.text:
I always wanted to maintain that.
But, being a blacksmith, my primary medium

230.text:
of work is through steel or iron, so that’s
what I know how to work, so that’s what

235.text:
we went with. And, also, it’s got a strength
to it that’s appropriate for an item this

241.text: large – a visual strength as well. So you’ve got these four rearing eagles holding this

246.text:
central, almost like totem-pole-type motif
in the centre, but also a physical strength

252.text: because something that tall needs to be able to support its own weight.

257.text:
I use a variety of tools, from electric to
mechanical and manual tools. So we have hammers,

266.text: anvils, we’ve got the forge – the old-fashioned way of forming metal by getting it hot and

270.text:
hammering it. I’m doing a lot of cutting
with grinders and dremels, but then the tidying

276.text: is quite often done with hand files and chisels and things like that.

280.text:
I’ll be using taps and dies to construct
things. I want to use as little electric welding

287.text:
as possible because it has a very obvious
visual impact. I want to use hidden joints,

294.text:
so you get these nice smooth lines on the
sculpture – nothing interfering and breaking

298.text:
those lines up when it’s fully constructed.
I really, really hope that this piece is going

306.text: to communicate the scale, the magnitude of importance of the Staffordshire Hoard: what

314.text: it tells us about the skills of these Anglo-Saxon craftsmen, their culture, their wealth,

321.text:
how they treat things in an almost ritual manner.
The deliberate destruction of a lot of these

327.text:
items sort of implies that they were ritually
killing the sword, taking away the sword’s

334.text:
own personality. The theory is that that sword
has been imbued by that person who owned it,

341.text:
so it itself has to be killed to remove that
power.

354.text:
Throughout my training and my early years
as a smith, I worked for other people, making

360.text:
things they told me to make. I never had any
creative input in what was being done. When

365.text:
I design things now, when I make things now,
the passion behind it is mine, the driving

371.text:
force is mine – I’m not doing it just
because I’m being paid.

373.text:
I love it because I see something through
from design, through making, through completion.

380.text:
I get pleasure from every stage of that, and
I can stand back – after all the sweat and

385.text:
the blood and the tears – and I can look
at something that’s finished and go:

389.text:
"I did that, with my hands. Like, just normal
human being hands. I did that. I took tools,

396.text:
I took metal in its bare form; I bent it,
I shaped it, and now it’s done.” And you

401.text:
get this sense of real achievement when you
create something with your own hands. I just

408.text:
think it’s fantastic, you know, being able
to make something from effectively nothing.
